 86 ANNEX 16 Page 1 of 7 SECOND SULAWESI URBAN DEVELOPMENT PROJECT SUMMARY OF ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT 1. Overall Context 1. A regional environmental assessment was completed by consultants to the Ministry of Public Work's Directorate General of Human Settlements, in close cooperation and consultation with local agencies and residents from March to June 1995. The infrastructure investments in IUIDP are designed to improve overall municipal management and minimize damages to the local environment. Efforts are needed to ensure that secondary environmental and social impacts are not caused by these investments. However, residual environmental problems may have more to do with contextual problems, rather than being a direct consequence of the investments themselves. It is, therefore, of greater value to analyze the environmental context as well as the impacts of the infrastructure investments in order to ensure that mitigation measures address the problems as a whole and not just those parts that are the consequence of the relatively small infrastructure investments. 2. The regional environmental assessment identified the main environmental problems in the Sulawesi Towns as: (a) health risks arising from contamination of domestic water sources, and especially domestic wells; (b) poor domestic sanitation contributing to chronic water pollution of local and other water bodies; (c) flooding, resulting in part from inadequate drainage, but exacerbated everywhere by drain blockage due to inadequate maintenance and solid waste; (d) poorly managed solid waste resulting in random dumping and accumulation along roadsides in and around the towns; (e) poorly located and managed official solid waste disposal sites that are often little or no improvement over random dumping; and (f) poorly managed markets which are unsanitary due to blocked drains accumulated solid waste, and inadequate or lacking water supply and/or sanitation facilities. 3. In addition to these generic problems, the various towns may be grouped according to their geographical features. Towns in more mountainous settings where soils are subject to erosion are more liable to experience flash flooding problems and much attention to drainage is required. Towns in flat, irrigated areas are also liable to flooding where inadequate attention is paid to filling ex-sawa (rice paddy) land. In coastal towns, houses built on stilts over tidal flats present difficult sanitary problems. 11. Analysis of Environmental Problems 4. Significant environmental issues identified in the environmental assessment include water resources, sanitation, flooding and drainage, solid waste management, construction impacts, traffic and accessibility impacts, industrial impacts, markets, parks and gardens, urban fringe problems, and regional resource management. The most important are outlined below. 5. Water Resources and Sanitation. The most serious problem related to water resources is contamination from human and solid waste. Most citizens have private toilets, but practically all toilets are connected to unlined pits. The main consequence is that ground water becomes increasingly polluted and wells are severely
 87 ANNEX 16 Page 2 of 7 contaminated. An associated concern is that open stormn water drains also contain human waste deposited directly or via seepage from poorly constructed toilet pits and poorly functioning septic tank outlets. 6. Flooding, and Drainaige. Although large scale flooding is relatively rare, many neighborhoods experience very regular flooding for short periods. The reasons include soil erosion; inadequate drainage systems; drain blockages; poor maintenance; the inherent difficulty of draining areas of ex-sawa (rice paddy); and housing in coastal towns being built on stilts over cleared mangroves. 7. Solid Waste Manapement. The problems include: the TPAs are difficult to service, hand carts are often not being used, only a small portion of waste disposed of by the public is collected; coordination between market management and solid waste authorities is poor; and formal disposal sites are usually just open dumps. Waste minimization and recycling are not part of the standard waste management model. 8. Construction Impacts. Construction inevitably disrupts daily life; however with poor management, these problems are exacerbated with: (a) poor planning and the works being completed more slowly than necessary; (b) untidy construction sites leading to additional dust, drain blockages and increased noise; and (c) inadequate attention to safety. 9. Markets. Two sets of persistent problems occur in markets. First, the needs of fresh food vendors are not adequately considered, resulting in conditions that not only affect the environment, but also pose a health risk to customers. Second, markets are generally poorly managed. Poor relations between market management and local goverments lead to inadequate service provision. 10. Parks and Gardens. In most towns some attention has been given to planting in pubic places and especially to lining streets with trees or planters. However, maintenance of public planting is generally sporadic and in many places unmaintained planters become depositories for rubbish. Vacant sites are common and remain unmaintained and attract solid waste dumping, giving them a general feel of dereliction. 11. Urban Fringe Problems and Regional Resource Management. The impact of urban development on the surrounding countryside and more broadly the resource implications of emerging development pattems are issues relevant to good urban management and to long-term environmental health and sustainability. The following points should be kept in mind. First, erosion causes siltation of rivers and drains, encouraging flooding. Second, all towns should have one property sited and operated solid waste disposal site. Third, upstream water extraction is based on convenience, without reference to the impact downstream. Fourth, urban expansion will reduce the efficiency of the irrigation systems. Fifth, many of the towns are expanding into natural forest areas of considerable value. Some serve as watershed protection areas upstream of springs used to for the town water supply system. Sixth and finally, the towns in the program are developing in a haphazard way, leading to extremely inefficient infrastructure provision. III. Mitigation, Management and Monitoring 12. The environmental analysis of each PJM identifies residual environmental problems that could be expected to persist following the PJM infrastructure investment unless appropriate measures are taken. In the environmental management framework, such measures fall into the two categories of mitigation and monitoring for which appropriate recommendations have to be made under the headings, respectively of UKL and UPL. In the process of completing the PJM environmental sections, a number of issues have repeatedly arisen where it has become clear that a common approach, in most cases supported by the Tk I agencies, or from the national government, would be appropriate.
 88 ANNEX 16 Page 3 of 7 13. Water Resources. Many towns would benefit from a survey of local water resources to ascertain the most cost-effective and appropriate sequence in which to tap the resources for the supply system. Such surveys could also indicate a measure to protect the water source. These surveys should also provide a basis for allocating the resources where there is potentially escalating competition between users. Some towns in this program are located in areas subject to intense irrigation, and competition for water between irrigation and urban supply needs is serious. The risks of contamination of domestic water supplies are well recognized and additional measures will need to be taken such as: (a) sampling by the PDAMs and bacteriological testing by the health department, but programs to deal with problems once encountered are in many cases still weak; (b) ambient water sources (rivers, canals, lakes) should also be sampled from time to time where these are used for bathing, washing and occasionally drinking; and (c) care in placing pipe-work needs to be taken. 14. Sanitation. Financing is to be made available and encouragement given to individual households without toilets to install them. The program will promote the installation of properly constructed septic tanks. In poorer and more congested areas, a program for constructing communal septic tanks is proposed. The program will also finance the purchase of a vacuum truck and the construction of a sludge treatment facility, generally located together with the solid waste disposal site. 15. A Real Demand Survey indicated that there is a lack of awareness of the potentially serious health problems associated with makeshift sanitary arrangements which currently prevail in all the towns. The fragmented programs and activities of the various agencies responsible for improving sanitary conditions need to be forged into a single integrated program with the following elements: (a) coordinating public education and training programs; (b) monitoring, encouraging and if necessary enforcing good practice; (c) monitoring domestic and ambient water; (d) using monitoring results to properly sequence improvements to water supply and sanitation; and (e) formulating proposals for further improvements in sanitation. 16. Drainage and Flood Control. Flooding and in general poor drainage are common problems in the towns in this program. None of the towns have a complete drainage system and few even have a proper main drainage and flood control plan. Such a plan is a first priority. Lack of maintenance of drains has also been highlighted as a problem in the PJMs and funding must be made available for maintenance. The following points are stressed: (a) Poor design and construction of local drainage systems are problems that must be overcome by the public works department taking a greater interest and control over the specification and construction of local drains; (b) Keeping drains clear requires preventive as well as remedial action. Preventive measures must include erosion control and other anti-siltation measures, avoiding laying pipes and cables through drains and eliminating the dumping of solid waste in drains; (c) The clearing of local drains needs to be turned into a formally organized regular activity; and (d) Difficulties in many towns that are expanding over mangrove swamps where houses on stilts are built on mud flat sites which were in the past flushed out by the tides, and are particularly difficult to provide with infrastructure. This problem must first be studied and a coherent set of measures proposed. 17. Solid Waste Management. The local governments' solid waste management systems currently serve only a small portion of the population. In many towns the quality of service is poor and the PJMs therefore call for appropriate institutional strengthening. Many PJMs recommend the establishment of composting facilities run by the local governments. In the past, a model for solid waste was promoted in which systems managed by
 89 ANNEX 16 Page 4 of 7 the local government were to be complemented by individual action and community involvement. The community has a vital role to play in any effective solid waste management system and this component therefore needs to be developed as follows: (a) Participating communities need to be empowered through motivation and organization. There must also be an effective incentive and cost-recovery system; (b) Until now the emphasis has been entirely on waste removal and disposal, a major shift is necessary towards waste reduction and reuse/recycling. The following activities should be developed: (i) households should be encouraged to separate organic waste from dry waste; (ii) where they have gardens, households should compost the organic part and use it for soil conditioning; (iii) local governments should help in the establishment of neighborhood materials collection systems; (c) Local governments need to attend closely to community systems, assisting, and where necessary, applying sanctions where residents fail in their responsibilities; and (d) In addition to their traditional waste management tasks, local governments should support waste reuse and recycling systems as noted above. 18. Solid Waste Disposal. There is a general need to improve both the choice of sites for final disposal of solid waste and the preparation and management of these sites. A number of crucial technical inputs must be included: (a) distance from other human activities; (b) ability to accommodate sufficient waste, (c) geomorphology; (d) hydrological and geological conditions; (e) local ecology; and (f) cost of land and cost of operations. Simple measures to make substantial improvements include: (a) where feasible, the choice of sites which have inherent management advantages; (b) pre-engineering of the sites; (c) simple leachate collection systems; (d) general control and management of the site and organizing waste picking activities. Consultants should be used to prepare the necessary drawings and supervise construction. However it is also important for local government waste managers to have a reasonable knowledge concerning the choice, preparation and good management practice of disposal sites. A well illustrated manual on the topic which must also include case studies covering different kinds of sites will be prepared and widely distributed. 19. Manainng Construction Impacts. These impacts need not be serious or last long, but a number of measures can be taken to ensure that they are minimized: (a) construction contractors should cooperate closely with police to agree on what work should be carried out and when, and how the traffic will be managed ii so far as road works are involved; (b) contractors should coordinate closely with other infrastructure agencies; (c) contractors should maintain work force discipline such that no nuisance is created; (d) measures should be taken to minimize any dust or mud and noise; (e) basic safety measures should be taken, including the training of the workforce; (f) work should be started only when all materials and resources are at hand, and minimal materials should be stored on site. These measures are generally already written into contracts for work on urban infrastructure. The onus is on the supervising contracting authorities to ensure that good site management is practiced. 20. Managing Transport Impacts and Improving Accessibility. The towns in this program are not yet suffering from significant problems relating to traffic, and the few instances of congestion mainly around bus terminals can be eliminated with relatively simple traffic management measures. 21. Market Improvements. Strong measures have to be taken to improve the management of markets. The following steps should be taken: (a) a new regime for market infrastructure development and management in wide consultation with market vendors, customers and managers should be developed; (b) a manual for market
 90 ANNEX 16 Page 5 of 7 design and construction should be produced; and (c) a training program should be developed and instituted for local government staff. 22. Parks and Gardens. Most local governments do spend money on parks and gardens and some towns have requested the inclusion of browsers for watering trees and street greenery in the framework of the solid waste management section of their PJM. Recommendations for improvement include tapping the resources of the communities and supporting parks department both to institute planting programs and to ensure that planting is well maintained. 23. Improved Management of Subregional Resources and Sustainable Development. In the hinterland of towns, which are suffering the threat of landslides, an active program of erosion control should be undertaken. This program would consider: (a) good soil management practices by farmers and estate managers; (b) planting for soil stabilization in areas subject to erosion; (c) infrastructure and housing development on slopes of easily eroded soils should be designed and built with the problem in mind; (d) quarrying, mining or other extraction should minimize erosion impacts; (e) illegal developments on unstable slopes or those which encourage erosion should be removed. 24. In addition to these elements, the effective confinement of solid waste to one well prepared and managed TPA site is important. The need for a more coherent and coordinated inventory and strategy for allocating and using subregional water resources is apparent. The protection of forest and nature reserves for the protection of water sources is noted. The haphazard and increasingly dispersed development of the towns in the program is arguably the most serious regional resource problem facing the urban subregions. The root cause is overpriced suburban land with poor planning machinery to "unlock"and reorganize land uses in these areas, coupled with cheap transport to more distant and cheaper land. More serious attention needs to be given to this in the planning and development of the towns in the program. This issue should become a major focus for strategic planning for the kabupatens. IV. Institutional Strengthening A. Procedural Issues 25. An attempt has been made to integrate environmental and social concems into the investment programs. The approach was to look not only at the environmental and social process more generally to see what problems need to be addressed. But there will remain residual problems and unless the investments are managed within a more coherent environmental and social management framework, they are liable to be suboptimal in their effectiveness. 26. If public consultation is undertaken on a program-wide basis, this incorporation of users into the decision-making process can be expected to begin to overcome the fragmentation of programs. An effective consultation process should be a cooperative enterprise among agencies, resulting in better integration of government programs. These main principles are: (a) more consideration needs to be given to communicating with the public in identifying priorities for infrastructure investments; (b) the aim should be to work toward consensus in the investments and a cooperative approach to their management;
 91 ANNEX 16 Page 6 of 7 (c) public information and training, and where appropriate, community self-management of programs, should be pursued; and (d) local government agencies should cooperate in organizing public consultation exercises. B. Institutional Recommendations 27. Conceming environmental and social monitoring and management as a whole, a number of recommendations are made. The law creating the national environmental protection agency (BAPEDAL) referred to the creation of provincial agencies. A new law should see that these provincial level agencies are established, first in the offices of the provincial governors, then in the kabupatens, starting in the spring or summer of 1996. Regional offices (BAPEDAL-Wilaya) are in the process of being established, with Sulawesi covered by the East Indonesia office in Ujung Pandang. This structure of environmental management should ensure that the environmental programs are implemented, but it is likely that BAPPEDA Tk II will have to fill this gap in the interim. 28. Specific institutional recommendations for solid waste management specify that where no formal waste management agency exists, one should be established and it should be provided with adequate resources. New arrangements to introduce a formal program for waste reduction and recycling of materials should be implemented. Local govemments, together with community organizations such as the women's organization PKK, should initiate composting arrangements. BAPPEDA Tk II needs to become involved. 29. Drainage. The provision of adequate drainage and the clearing of blocked drains need to be addressed urgently. Although more funding for O&M might be appropriate, encouragement and censure need to be instituted to ensure that the work is carried out. The induction of local institutions (Kelurahan, LKD and RW) where appropriate would be desirable. 30. Market Planning and Management. The institutional structure in place seems inadequate where the condition of markets is almost universally unsanitary and poorly managed. There is an urgent need for greater consultation conceming the location and planning of market arrangements. This situation implies the need to establish standing committees on market planning and management. C. Initiatives in Education and Training 31. The Ministry of Health has pioneered public education and training and has a lot of experience at all government levels from the big cities through small towns into the rural areas. The initiative which is recommended here is to apply a much more integrated approach to education, training and consultation. There are four main areas in which such training exercises are recommended. 32. Sanitation. This is seen as an umbrella concept under which all four areas are gathered. This is in part because the main environmental problems in the towns all relate to sanitation, be it from unsatisfactory human waste management, flooding, poor solid waste management, or the condition of the markets. The sanitation campaigns already undervay form a good foundation on which to build a more substantial training and consultative process. These training sessions should include workshops for the staff of all the departments and community representatives concemed, and as well as for community groups. 33. Drainage. The focus of training around the problem of poor drainage must be predominantly concemed with mechanisms for ensuring that drains are kept clear.
 92 ANNEX 16 Page 7 of 7 34. Solid Waste Management. Training workshops need to bc held in which the responsible local officials and community representatives receive instruction and agree on roles to achieve an effective collection service. Manuals and training materials for this need to be produced and motivation raised. The courses for local waste disposal staff should be implemented in the context of this program. 35. Markets. Two aspects of market organization require urgent attention. On the one hand, the planning and reconstruction of markets under way in many of the towns requires more consideration of the needs of all market users. On the other hand, the day-to-day running of the wet markets to achieve and sustain the maintenance of sanitary conditions requires serious attention. A group of training modules for the staff of Dinas Pasar also needs to be attended by staff of other departments. These modules should cover all aspects of the management, keeping drains clean and managing solid waste. It is also suggested that the continued good management of the market, which concems both economic and sanitation issues, would best be guaranteed by the establishment of a Market Forum that would bring together representatives of the responsible agencies.

General Methodology The evaluation criteria are based mainly on the net benefit stream for the economic analysis and on the corresponding net revenues for the financial analysis. Internal rates of return (IRR) and Net Present Value (NPV) have been included as additional indicators. Sensitivity testing has been undertaken, limited, however, to 10 percent increases to costs and revenues respectively, but calculated on separate runs. IRR's have been calculated without interest, depreciation and inflation, but including replacement costs, where applicable, and salvage values. Salvage values were generally estimated at 20 percent, representing a generally acceptable rate for the mix of short life components (e.g. vehicles) and long life components such as permanent structures. Depreciation, where applicable, will be calculated on a simple straight-line formula. Economic analysis has been carried out at constant 1996 prices. In order to convert financial into economic costs, applying to Drainage sub-programs only, a standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9 has been used. Lacking specific information, it is assumed that the SCF chosen will eliminate any economic distortions of market prices which may prevail at present (taxes, subsidies). Consequently, it is believed that economic prices will thus best reflect the real value to society of costs and benefits which will result from the proposed sub-projects. Operation and maintenance (O&M) costs, resulting from the implementation of the individual sub- programs, have not been taken from the PJM where they are shown in absolute terms. They have instead been based on standard percentage rates according to general experiences in the different sectors. Besides, uniform O&M rates offer the advantage of allowing a more reliable comparison of the outcome of sub-programs of individual cities. The applied rates are as follows: * Water supply: 15.0 percent (an optimistic assumption as performance of Sulawesi PDAMs indicate a range of 12% to 25%) * Solid wvaste 15.0 percent * Bus terminals 2.0 percent * all sectors 2.5 percent Since the determination of revenues (for financial analysis) and benefits (for economic analysis) vary considerably according to the character of the sub-sector concerned, corresponding methods applied have been described individually for specific sub-programs. Summary Tables showing the evaluation results have been prepared, and the Evaluation Tables for each town and per sector have been attached in the Annexes to the Report on Economic and Financial Analysis of Subprojects which is in the Project File.
 96 ANNEX 18 Page 2 of 3 2. Water Supply Basic Considerations Extensions to the existing water production capacity and extension of the water distribution system in operation, form a major component of the proposed development program in almost all towns evaluated. A key problem of the planned investment programs is that the proposals usually involve a mixture of changes and improvements to the current services. Extensions to the network together with an enlarged production capacity are regularly combined with rehabilitation of weak or non-operational components of the existing system, including all water-loss reduction schemes and reconnection of shut-off connections, where applicable. The number of persons per connection in Year One is assumed to be seven, allowing for some shared consumption by neighbors. The figure is gradually reduced in future years to allow for expected reductions in average household size. It is assumed that the average per capita consumption (ranging from 100-120 VcJd) will remain constant over the planning period since any tendency for consumption to rise with general increase in incomes is balanced by the well-known fact that new PDAM customers will have significantly lower incomes than existing customers. Consumption from non-domestic connections and public hydrants is taken as 1,000 liters/day. Water losses will correspond to losses currently experienced by individual PDAM. However, a standard rate of 30% has been targeted as future value to be retained in the analysis. Exception will be made where actual water losses are already below 30%. For those towns Bulukumba (24.8%), Palopo (27.8%), and Sinjai (21.3%) a minimum improvement has still been assumed. For the financial analysis of those programs exceeding investments of Rp 4,000 million, the FINPRO model has been used for a detailed analysis which will be found on the Project File. Results Only some ten programs out of about 35 water supply investment programs examined are economically justified if the sole criteria of an intemal rate of return (FIRR) of 12% is used. In view of the above results, it was agreed that in addition, technically sound programs based on a least-cost-solution, actual demand and increased service levels required by the beneficiaries, should also be eligible for inclusion.  97 ANNEX 18 Page 3 of 3 At least the first three of above indicators point in the direction of unsatisfactory relations with customers, otherwise a key element for successful cost recovery policies, and rather poor management capacities of some of the PDAM staff. Additionally, institutional weaknesses have been noted in form of overstaffing. A ratio of twenty employees or more per 1,000 connections, which does not seem to be the exception in many PDAM in Sulawesi, will negatively impact the financial success of any PDAM. Well organized enterprises guarantee efficient services with a ratio of ten or less employees per 1,000 connections. Taking the above considerations into account, the approach to examine the new investment programs for water supply on their own, has been revised and the investment has been tested as to its impact if combined with the existing situation prevailing in each PDAM. This may be the more logical approach since significant portions of the new investment programs are to be used for rehabilitation purposes and service improvements with little impact on extra recurrent costs, but greater impacts on revenue generation (e.g. re-connection of shut- off connections). As a direct result, ten additional programs (Barru, Bulukumba, Enrekang, Maros. Palopo, Pangkep, Sinjai, Watampone, Poso and Kendari) became acceptable in financial/economic terms. Emphasis will be put on management, institutional and operations improvements. All analyses have been based on the tariffs and billing rates currently applied by the corresponding PDAMs. Thus a great variety of charge rates for water have been used, ranging from 72 Rp/m3 (Sinjai) to 691 Rp/m3 (Maros), with the average being 309 Rp/m3 (which has been used where corresponding information was lacking). Furthermore, the charge rates have been increased by generally 20-50% (up to 100% in some cases) in two equal steps in Year Two and Year Four of project implementation where this was required to reach the desired outcome. Lower increases have been accepted where the outcome was more promising. 3. Drainage The overwhelming majority of drainage subprojects are very small, i.e. cost less than Rp 500 million (about $0.2 million). Case by case economic analysis (i.e. calculation of EIRR and NPV) is required only for the larger ones which typically cost Rp 600 million to Rp 3 billion. The benefits of these drainage subprojects are estimated on the basis of land value increases due to reduced flooding. The advantage of this approach is obvious: land value increase, if land markets function properly, is an indicator which can reflect the present value of the future benefit stream accruing to the owners of the land in the project area. The projected increases in land values are based on comparison of land values in the project area to land values in similar, but less frequently flooded neighborhoods. Information on land values for the subprojects was collected during interviews with kelurahan (sub-district) staff handling land transactions and with informal real estate brokers.

doc.abstracts: The main development objective of the Second Sulawesi Urban Development Project is to improve the delivery of urban infrastructure services by local governments on a sustainable basis. The more specific operational objectives of the project include: a) improving the provision of urban services; b) strengthening operations and maintenance activities for urban services and support improved planning, programming, budgeting, financial management and local revenues generation by local governments; and c) improving urban environmental management and reducing local environmental impacts. The project will not only fund infrastructure investments and their related needs, but will also support a comprehensive implementation support strategy. The infrastructure works to be carried out under the project include: a) urban planning; b) water supply; c) human waste/sanitation; d) drainage and flood control; e) urban roads; f) solid waste management; g) KIP - Kampung Improvement Program; h) markets and transport terminals; i) detailed design; and j) resettlement.
